In this age of crises careful stucfy of the fourth item is the most urgent* Its
application extends beyond the educational television station—at least until
a sufficient number of well-run and well-financed operations of this type cover
the major elements of our population. (Were the latter to be the case this
might be ideal.)
What I am trying to say is in terms of Lazarsfeld the mass media, if effectively
used, must utilize the factors of REPETITION and WIDE EXPOSURE. No idea stated
a single time to a small audience accomplishes its purpose* The mass media
creates attitudes and impressions much more effectively than they transmit
skills and particularized knowledge. In effect, one must more often use a
paint brush than a scalpel* The consideration is that the paint be a bonafide
product and the brush strokes done with ethics and understanding as well as
with virtuosity.
The obligation of educational television is to serve all of these people and all
of these needs, but it must first examine the basic current needs and the tech¬
niques indicated for meeting the problem rather than taking comfortable refuge
in "museum type”, "library-type”, and "comfortable cultural” thinking.
